page.title: 04ECOLOGY - SULLINGTON
page.content: Much of the chalk downs has been put down to arable crops, but the slopes still reflect remnants of downland turf and the associated flor - orchids, yellow rattle, harebells, cowslips, campion etc., which attracts the chalk blue and orange tip butterflies. One can also find the brimstone, peacock, red admiral, tortoiseshell and gatekeeper butterflies. There are badgers and adders, and rabbits are once more grazing here, their return helping to inhibit the encroachment of shrubs and course grass. There is a wide variety of birds, including woodpeckers, yellowhammers, gold crests, linnets, and fen birds, including the cornbunting can be seen.
